ceterms:description.en: This badge represents the completion of at least 20 ETE digital badges and both of the culminating certificates.
Earn a Contribute badge by having a proposal accepted and your article published in a peer reviewed academic teaching journal.

Foundations Forum events focus on specific subjects and occur throughout the year. These sessions supplement the August Foundations event and focus on topics helpful to the cohort, such as student engagement, faculty resources and more.
Offered both Fall and Spring semesters.

ceterms:name.en: Teaching Related Workshop or Conference Off-Campus (Contribute)

ceterms:description.en: Off-campus workshops or conferences focused on teaching may be general or disciplinary-based. The experience may be a conference session that is a larger part of a scholarly meeting.

The Journal on Empowering Teaching Excellence accepts proposals from instructors and other higher education professionals to promote, share, and discuss emerging ideas in teaching and learning. Earn a Contribute badge by having your proposal accepted and your presentation published.
On-campus workshops or conferences focused on teaching may be general or disciplinary-based. The experience may be a conference session that is a larger part of a scholarly meeting.

The Seminar Series features speakers selected from USU's faculty and occasional visiting guest speakers. Topics pertain to various aspects of effective teaching and primarily focus on practical application, learned through experience, by seasoned teachers.

Podcasts are a great way to learn in an informal setting about current trends in the field of teaching and how ideas are being implemented. The ETE Podcast and other teaching podcasts frequently host guests to share their perspectives and expertise on teaching.

The ETE program is organized by a committee made up of faculty representatives who help determine topics, guest speakers, and also provide insight, ideas, and support as needed. Members of the committee receive a Contribute badge.

This event will energize and inspire you as you begin the next teaching year. Presentations are faculty submitted, faculty led, and focused on teaching innovations that have worked well here at USU. Topics and presenters span multiple disciplines and delivery formats. Invitees include all who teach at USU, regardless of role statement or campus, including graduate student instructors and teaching assistants.

This event will energize and inspire you as you begin the next teaching year. Presentations are faculty submitted, faculty led, and focused on teaching innovations that have worked well here at USU. Topics and presenters span multiple disciplines and delivery formats. Invitees include all who teach at USU, regardless of role statement or campus, including graduate student instructors and teaching assistants.

Foundations of USU Teaching is a cohort-based program for new instructor development. The workshop will focus on helping new faculty to: prepare effective syllabi and appropriately set classroom expectations, prepare for end-of-semester teaching evaluations, learn how student characteristics and demographics affect and influence the teaching/learning environment, learn to use teaching resources such as Canvas and the library, and apply principles of effective teaching.

This badge is earned by providing peer review feedback on a course for another USU instructor. Using one the approved course design or teaching rubrics, this interaction provides an opportunity for peer reviewers to give feedback specific to the course material (subject matter), course design, or teaching technique.
Completion of presenting and/or contributing at an ETE event or workshop.

ceterms:name.en: USU Libraries Revamp Assignment Interdisciplinary Workshop (Contribute)

ceterms:description.en: Attend and participate in USU libraries' revamp your research assignment: An interdisciplinary faculty charrette. Bring an assignment for review. Review other faculties' assignments, give feedback for assignments, and receive feedback from on your assignment. Participate in large group reflections, and fill out feedback survey.

The Open Education Resources badge encourages the use of open educational resources (OER). OER are teaching, learning, and research resources released under an open license that permits their free use and repurposing by others. These can include open access scholarly and educational resources and texts that faculty create themselves. 

The goal of the badge is to incentivize faculty members to adopt, adapt, and create alternatives to high priced commercial textbooks. The tiers will be determined by whether projects focus on revising and remixing resources to creating new open content or projects that result in substantially new open textbooks. Encouraging faculty members to create or adapt OER reduces cost barriers and allows every student immediate and unlimited access to learning materials from day one of a class.

The Graduate Training Series (GrTS) is an opportunity for USU’s graduate students to augment their studies with professional development that will prepare them for the next steps along their career paths. With experts from across campus, grad students from all disciplines gather to develop skillsets that will set them apart as strong professionals in their fields. Offered at various times -

ceterms:description.en: Teaching Podcasts are generally less formal, and engage the speaker individually through an interview format. Teaching Podcasts are recorded and stored on their podcast channel for the listeners convenience. There are dozens of teaching podcast, however, the podcasts listed below are approved for reflection on this assignment.

ceterms:name.en: CIDI Workshop - Usable and Accessible Course Design (Engage)

ceterms:description.en: The Graduate Training Series (GrTS) is an opportunity for USU’s graduate students to augment their studies with professional development that will prepare them for the next steps along their career paths. With experts from across campus, grad students from all disciplines gather to develop skillsets that will set them apart as strong professionals in their fields.

CIDI workshops are a gathering of instructors who have an interest in using technologies effectively to deliver pedagogical techniques in blended models and learner-focused instruction. Workshops that qualify are Writing Objectives, Introduction to Canvas, Flipping the Classroom, Introduction to Online Teaching, Planning an Online Course, and Online Accessibility. For more information including upcoming events visit: Aggie Sync.
On-campus workshops or conferences focused on teaching may be general or disciplinary-based. The experience may be a conference session that is a larger part of a scholarly meeting.

Prepares graduate students for college teaching. Students learn to prepare study guides, examinations, and lectures, and learn to use audio-visual aids. Students also examine various current methods of instruction and course evaluation schemes.

ceterms:name.en: Remote Teaching & Learning Analytics Web Series (Engage)

ceterms:description.en: Using the latest approaches in learning analytics and the learning sciences, this webinar series is designed to help faculty optimize their courses for remote delivery.

6 - Engage level badges
3 - Implement level badges
1 - Contribute level badge
+ Teaching Philosophy

The ETE Scholar Awards program provide a small award (up to $4000) to support a cohort of USU instructors (5-7 individuals) to engage in the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning (SoTL). The Scholar Award program not only provides funding for professional development and resources associated with a SoTL project, but it also provides support in the development, implementation, and dissemination process.

10 - Engage level badges
6 - Implement level badges
4 - Contribute level badges
